Wanted to get down some notes on this...

Pour from a bag-in-a-box (Thanks Levi!) is a very clear, surprisingly dark amber pour with no head. No lacing to speak of. Aroma is wet wood notes, with the oak being more prominent than I would have thought, especially when it¬ís pointed out. Very "funky" smelling, in a cheesy, wet dog, sweaty sock sort of way, without becoming overpowering or off putting. A bit of the lactic and citric tartness for which Girardin Black Label is known pushes through and really brightens up the experience. The pineapple and grapefruit is there, but quite subdued. Taste is a fair bit of that same funk, more tart than the aroma lets on. The malt profile is surprisingly present, with a fair bit of caramel character, and quite a bit of that Cheerio/cracker character on the finish that I have often gotten in some young bottled home-brewed sours (And often attribute to priming sugar/residual extract). Caramel malt character. A vegetal note that I attribute to hops, though without the bitterness/pithyness that we have gotten in some of our beers brewed with aged hops...better source/older hops? Finish is fairly drying, with the classic Girardin sour elements of citrus fruit and bright acidity. Still quite a bit of body for a sour beer, and a flat one at that. Overall, a very unique experience that has made me think a lot about the state of some of our "young" sour projects. Very fun to see where some of Girardin¬ís beer starts...a really interesting and surprising experience to be sure.

Draught @ Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2008. Clear deep golden with no head. Sweet and sour with barnyard and apple notes. Ends sour.

From 5 liter Tap at Plan B, Copenhagen. Pours clear orange with absolutely no head or lacings. Aroms is fresh, tart, old, woody & fruity apples.Good bite & quite sticky. Very low carbonation. Earthy original & real! Nice treat!

Tap @ Plan B., Cph.
Pours clear golden with no head. Aroma is tart, but with a sugary sweetness and lots of oaky wood. Almost completely flat, small, tiny bubbles on the tongue. Flavour is softly tart, lots of fresh oakiness, good lactic sourness and funkiness. Stays on my teeth all the way through!
Bag-in-box. Pours a clear amber with no head. Low sourness and sweetness. Extremely low carbonation. Hints of cork. Fruity aromas of apples and grapes.
Bag-In-Box at Plan B. Clear amber - white head. Sourness, woody, light sweetness, light candy sugar, apples, fruity, smooth. Very nice.

Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2008.  12-18 months old.  Clear and still honey color.  Nose of wet dog, honey, light perfumed fruit, etc.  Vinuous up front with some medium-sweet malt (honey, sugar), then gets a little prickly over the middle.  Very mild, quiet and clean, and vinuous and soft.  Not nearly as good as the jong, which was spectacular, but still quite serviceable.  Lacks the cheesy-feet funky smell of the younger version, and is more wine-like as well.

[1166-20080301] Cask. Mild yeasty sourness and wet plant aroma. Clear, brown yellow body with quick white bubbles. Mildly sour yeast flavour with a hint of malt in the background. Medium body is fairly smooth. Good and interesting to try but not exactly unique here.
(ZBF 2008; Sint Niklaas, BE)
Clear dark-yellow amber color. Tartness in the nose and flavours. A bit musty. Sticky mouthfeel. Long lasting sourish aftertaste.
hazy amber coloured beer with no carbonation and no head. Sour fruity aroma with some oak/wooden touches. Medium light sour palate. Finish is bitter herby, ferm and sour. Nice.
Clear amber coloured beer with no head and no carbonation. Sour aroma. Full little sour palate. Finish is little sour and herby ending sweeter. Nice one.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2008 I¬íd the luck to taste it in ¬í04 & ¬í05 version in session. The first were really acetic but still nice, woody, fruity. The younger  more complex, with strong cellar notes, such as those of a well crafted "salame", citric and barnyardy along with that fantastic fruitiness. Both lovely and quenching.
(3/1/08) Draught sample at Zythos Bier Festival 2008 in Sint Niklaas. Clear golden with no head. Very nice barnyard aroma. Sour flavor with wood and citrus. Good rounded mouthfeel.
Draught at ZBF08. Good sourness and cellar notes in aroma and flavour. Cloudy amber colour. Good flavour, some CO2.

ZBF 08. Pours a clear dark golden color with a ring of offwhite lace on top. The aroma is sour, cheesy and musty. The flavor is intense on the sourness with some cheese flavor and a musty presence. The body is light to medium with an oily texture and gentle carbonation. Since I love both Black label and White label gueuzes, I thought that sampling the unblended lambic would be awesome, it¬ís not the case, but it¬ís still very good and I¬ím very happy to have tasted it at the festival.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2009 750 ml bottle shared by Armand at Tria and a 10 liter box shared by Puzzl about 15 months apart.  Pours flat and looks exactly like the jonge lambic- nice clear beautiful tawny, biscuity and similar appearance to a nice scotch or whiskey.  Aroma is a bit more woody, and more funky- but still has an off sweetness- ligth acidity, with some garbage and just off smells- boxed version is cleaned up a bit but has more acetaldehyde and solventy acetone notes, green apple, light sugary sweetness and hints of both dms and diacetyl.  Flavor is a bit bland- some spongy cork, dusty oak and wood, some weird off funk, off metallic astringency and just not pleasant.  Finish isnt as smooth or even as acidic as the jonge lambic- how the hell does that work?  Box was better than the bottle- being a bit more complex, not as thin or watery, still tons of acetaldehyde and strange wild acids that may mellow in time- a bit more horsey and funky- may just be a slightly better batch this time- but overall quite similar to what I remmeber in the bottle when Armand shared some with us. This  bottle was the only thing I couldn¬ít finish along with the lindemans kriek we had that night at Tria.  The Cantillon 1900 absolutely destroys this beer, but I think there must have been something off- must try again in amsterdam, and luckily I have a nice 1 literbottle of this from Bierkoning!  Will try agian soon and re-rate.    Box was much better than bottle, and I was able to drink about 5 glasses of the boxed example that we had.

[Tria Fermentation School] Poured a still, clear, dark amber color, that left no head or lace on the glass.  Aroma of sherry, light wood, floral, dusty and horsey, with some brett beginning to show through.  The flavor was more well rounded, with the sourness taking a bit of a back seat, and letting the tart grapes, vanilla, perfume, lemon peel, fig and pine show through.

Keg (ZBF2008)
Pale gold, no head. Sharp aroma. Lovely sweet body with a crisp sharp edge and a little wood too. Solid unblended lambic, good example of the style.

2008-03-01. Crisp golden amber body is near headless. Very mild aroma, light not quite fruity, wheaty notes. Smells much like the other faros and lambics of the day. Tart sour flavour with a light ambiguous fruit character, pleasant sourness throughout, hints of lemons and some underlying malt. Average palate. Good, but not nearly as complex as some of their other offerings. The bartender is apparently showing off for a lady and the cork he sends over the top of the booth almost hits me!On tap at Zythos Festival, St. Niklaas

ZBF2008: Oude lambic (houten vat). Pours slight hazy orange, little lacing head. Aroma is light acidc with a mild woody note. Flavour is dry acidic to mild citric, very smooth. Also light butterish and with a mild vanilla note. Ends dry and acidic to woody.

Sampled draught at ZBF 2008.
Deep golden, no head.
Fruity and not very sour at all.
Soft and smooth palate.
A bit short flavour.

On tap at ZBF 08.  Toffeeish, not so sour as some of the other lambics.  The age has tempered it.  Quite drinkable, nicest flavours of the lambics so far.  Not as good as a young bottle of the oude geuze I had in Gent the night before.
Draught at Zythos beer festival 2008. Clear orange golden with some bubbles. Cidery with grapefruit and some vinegar notes. Light to medium bodied with good mouthfeel. Well balanced.
Hazy amber of color with a light white head. An aroma of sour wood, oak, horse and sour notes. A flavor of grapefruits and oak, sour notes.

Sample from 10L box from brewery.  Dry red wine and vinegar aroma.  Clear amber color with short lasting head.  Initially smooth malty flavor followed by a sour/tart vinegar flavor in the middle and finishes back with a nice malty finish.  Sourness much less pronounced than with their gueuzes - a work of art.

On draft at Het Warm Water, Brussels March 2007. Deep, slightly hazy gold with a big but short-lived white head. Aroma of the barnyard, an almost savoury sourness, slightly sweet citrus and oak. mouth feel was vinous with sweet fruit and sour flavours followed by a very long, dry finish. Thirst quenching and excellent.

On draught, or rather, from the jug at the Karakterbierfest in Poperinge. Easily my favorite thing I tasted at the fest. Intense, grapefruity, tart and flat with just a touch of tea-like sweetness. Also some lemon and apples and must in there, I thought. Looked like fresh cider with a few sparse bubbles on top.  Awesome and refreshing. Each sip was a sort of "wow" moment.

Not sure how old this is. It was obtained on draught during 2007¬ís GBBF. jbrus, the expert of the table, considered it was probably relatively young. It is definitely the Oude version though. Dark orange shade, clearish. Flowery, perfumey aroma with bright, rather fresh orange blossom and tea-like grapefruit. Stupendous. Very classy, elegant, balanced from start to finish. Flat bodied with fair fruity, white grape tannins. Lots of evolving floral notes. Not so funky at this age, more playing the classy game. Friendly yeast, but complex and quite intense. In a very pleasant phase of its evolution at this age. Remarkabe quality.

Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 07.    Gold, slight hints of ruby.  Nose is fruity, very light caramel, a bit of vaguely orangely lemon.  Flavor is bitter acid at first, yielding to a very nice sweet/sour play.  Some light caramel in the acidic finish.
